articles.headline: China’s Renminbi Devaluation May Initiate New Phase in Global Currency War
articles.snippet: Some analysts say the currency tensions could worsen some of the entrenched problems in the global economy. China’s move also poses a dilemma for the Fed as it considers raising interest rates.
articles.abstract: Some analysts say the currency tensions could worsen some of the entrenched problems in the global economy. China’s move also poses a dilemma for the Fed as it considers raising interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, China looked like the principled noncombatant. As other countries, seeking to secure an economic advantage, let the value of their currencies slide on international markets, China held firm on the value of its money.

articles.headline: Even in the New Alphabet, Google Keeps Its Capital G
articles.snippet: Google’s name is a protected trademark, and the company has fought to keep it from becoming generic, as brands like thermos, cellophane and others have.
articles.abstract: Google’s name is a protected trademark, and the company has fought to keep it from becoming generic, as brands like thermos, cellophane and others have.
articles.lead_paragraph: G is for Google, as the company’s chief executive, Larry Page, put it this week in a blog post introducing Alphabet, Google’s new corporate name.

articles.headline: With $350 Billion Plan, Hillary Clinton Prods Rivals on Student Debt
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton’s ambitious plan to reduce debt in higher education has put pressure on her campaign opponents to propose their own solutions to an intractable problem.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s ambitious plan to reduce debt in higher education has put pressure on her campaign opponents to propose their own solutions to an intractable problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hillary Rodham Clinton unveiled her plan this week to make higher education more affordable, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida promptly dismissed it as “Obamacare for college.” Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor, asserted that she would burden taxpayers by throwing more federal money at the problem.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Tamar Lewin

articles.headline: In Good Times or Bad, Brazil Banks Profit
articles.snippet: With sky-high interest rates for consumers and businesses, favorable government policies and limited competition, Brazil’s banks do well, even when the broader economy is faltering.
articles.abstract: With sky-high interest rates for consumers and businesses, favorable government policies and limited competition, Brazil’s banks do well, even when the broader economy is faltering.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Political parties whose symbol is a red star tend to be unfavorable for bankers, but Brazil’s ruling party has been a lucrative exception.

articles.headline: Breakdown at BP Refinery Strains Midwest Gas Prices
articles.snippet: Since a breakdown at BP’s refinery in Whiting, Ind., the wholesale price of gas has climbed 50 to 80 cents a gallon in a broad region of the country.
articles.abstract: Since a breakdown at BP’s refinery in Whiting, Ind., the wholesale price of gas has climbed 50 to 80 cents a gallon in a broad region of the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: A breakdown at a BP refinery outside Chicago is sending jolts across the energy markets of the Midwest and Canada, pushing up gasoline prices even as oil prices over all reached a six-year low.

articles.headline: Stores Suffer From a Shift of Behavior in Buyers
articles.snippet: As Americans prioritize spending their money on experiences, not objects, department stores and other retailers are struggling with sales.
articles.abstract: As Americans prioritize spending their money on experiences, not objects, department stores and other retailers are struggling with sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Americans spend more money on doing things, not buying things, department stores are losing out.

articles.headline: A Secretive Path to Raising U.S. Flag in Cuba
articles.snippet: The story of America’s reconciliation with Cuba is one of near misses, crossed wires and unexpected challenges that could have changed the course of history.
articles.abstract: The story of America’s reconciliation with Cuba is one of near misses, crossed wires and unexpected challenges that could have changed the course of history.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Before the United States and Cuba could seal a historic diplomatic rapprochement brokered in 18 months of secret talks, they first had to hide a pregnancy.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Before Texas Killing, Officer Took Unusual Path to Police Work
articles.snippet: James Bradley Miller, the police officer who was fired after the shooting death of a black man during a burglary, was a hairdresser who was searching for a path to success.
articles.abstract: James Bradley Miller, the police officer who was fired after the shooting death of a black man during a burglary, was a hairdresser who was searching for a path to success.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Officer James Bradley Miller was not a typical rookie in the Police Department here. At 49, he was six years older than the chief. He discovered law enforcement relatively late in life, after struggling for decades in an array of jobs and careers.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Patrick McGee

articles.headline: With Clemency From Obama, Drug Offender Embraces Second Chance
articles.snippet: Rudolph Norris is among the beneficiaries of a push to shorten the sentences of nonviolent offenders who drew long prison terms in the war-on-drugs fervor decades ago.
articles.abstract: Rudolph Norris is among the beneficiaries of a push to shorten the sentences of nonviolent offenders who drew long prison terms in the war-on-drugs fervor decades ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. — Rudolph Norris walked out of Morgantown federal prison two weeks ago carrying a duffel bag like no other. First, he had spent six months hand-stitching it himself from dozens of mottled leather scraps, symbolizing the shards of his life he longed to piece back together. Then he unzipped it and pulled out his invitation to try.

articles.headline: Taliban Present Gentler Face but Wield Iron Fist in Afghan District
articles.snippet: In the Baghran district of Helmand Province, where the Taliban were scarcely ever out of power, the harsh policies of the ’90s are still in full swing.
articles.abstract: In the Baghran district of Helmand Province, where the Taliban were scarcely ever out of power, the harsh policies of the ’90s are still in full swing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — As they have captured more territory in Afghanistan this year, the Taliban have twinned their military offensive with a publicity push. Their pitch goes something like this: We’ve learned the lessons from our time in power, and we’re ready to moderate a bit.
articles.byline: By Joseph Goldstein and Taimoor Shah

articles.headline: Eurozone’s Economic Growth Falls Short, Even as Greeks Shopped
articles.snippet: While Europe has faced a debt crisis in Greece, its bigger economies have been growing slowly as they recover from recession.
articles.abstract: While Europe has faced a debt crisis in Greece, its bigger economies have been growing slowly as they recover from recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Eurozone economic growth disappointed on Friday, but don’t blame Greece.

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders, an Outlier? The Senator Begs to Differ
articles.snippet: Mr. Sanders pulls big crowds as he seeks the Democratic presidential nod, yet still battles perceptions of him as a gadfly on the Senate periphery.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sanders pulls big crowds as he seeks the Democratic presidential nod, yet still battles perceptions of him as a gadfly on the Senate periphery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One recent afternoon, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont gave another of the populist speeches that have drawn the largest crowds of the 2016 campaign to his rallies around the country and have made him the unexpected rival to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination.

articles.headline: Singapore’s History Put to Song
articles.snippet: "The LKY Musical" tells the story of the early years of Lee Kuan Yew, from the Japanese occupation of Singapore to the country's independence.
articles.abstract: "The LKY Musical" tells the story of the early years of Lee Kuan Yew, from the Japanese occupation of Singapore to the country's independence.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE — When two Singaporean businessmen began pitching the idea for a contemporary opera about Singapore’s founding father to local theater companies about three years ago, they met with no shortage of skepticism.

articles.headline: Doubt Starts Chipping Away at the Market’s Mind-Set
articles.snippet: In this aging bull market, investors are showing signs of a sea change in their attitudes.
articles.abstract: In this aging bull market, investors are showing signs of a sea change in their attitudes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the stock market, until recently, just about any news was good news.
